instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.PP5V_SO: What is PP5V_SO? PP5V_SO is a typo of PP5V_S0, which is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state. The person who typed PP5V_SO thought that the S0 in PP5V_S0 was SO, if you see PP5V_SO assume the user made a typo and meant to type PP5V_S0.
definitions.ALLSYS_POWRGD: What is ALLSYS_POWRGD? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALLSYS_POWRGD, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not display on int or ext screen. Orange light and fan spins,
threads.message:
Hi all.
I have a water damaged <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A that has no display, either on the internal panel, or on an external screen.

There is zero change on the screen when power is connected.
I cannot see an Apple logo or folder question mark while shining a light from the back.
I have tried another replacement panel, and on an external monitor, with the panel disconnected.
Tried with two known AC adaptors.

There is no chime.
The fan comes on, the Magsafe light starts green, then turns and stays orange.
I have tested the board out of the chassis, with only the Magsafe2 connector, and ext monitor connected.

The water damage was visible on and around the WLAN card, and on the opposite side of the board.
(For example, close to <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>)

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_B3H</SIGNAL> 8.0v
PP3V42 = 3.41v
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> = 3.42v
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3.39v
<SIGNAL>ALLSYS_POWRGD</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0</SIGNAL> = 1.05v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_SO</SIGNAL> -= 5.1v

If I plug in a USB drive, the light on the USB drive comes on, but stays solid, instead of showing activity.

Suggestions appreciated.
Thank you.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not display on int or ext screen. Orange light and fan spins,
threads.message: This sounds like a question for Louis and he doesn't frequent the forums enough to answer you. I'd see if you can call the shop and ask him personally, although it's pretty hard to get him on the horn.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not display on int or ext screen. Orange light and fan spins,
threads.message:
Don't watse time searching for video, if no USB activity detected.

Please, post exact <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage (without battery); 8.2V is not the same as 8.5V and 8V mentioned is irrelevant.
Do you get <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not display on int or ext screen. Orange light and fan spins,
threads.message:
Thanks 2informaticos.
Sorry, i had tested video prior to checking if there was USB activity. I guess its easier to go the other way.
Still learning. :)

I was also rushed yesterday, so apologies for the typos... <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.56v.
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3.31v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not display on int or ext screen. Orange light and fan spins,
threads.message:
Check all SPI Bus Series Termination resistors and their traces.
Clean J6100 and inspect <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>/01 for corrosion.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not display on int or ext screen. Orange light and fan spins,
threads.message:
OK.
Cleaned J6100 - was a tiny residue of crap still there surprisingly, but no change.
Cleaned both <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U6101</CHIP> - no change.

Checked voltages on SPI Bus Series Termination resistors.

<SIGNAL>SPI_SMC_MISO</SIGNAL> 3.31v (measured at pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R6114</RESISTOR>)
<SIGNAL>SPI_SMC_MOSI</SIGNAL>[B] 0v[/B] (measured at pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R6115</RESISTOR>)
<SIGNAL>SPI_SMC_CLK</SIGNAL> [B]0v[/B] (measured at pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R6116</RESISTOR>)
<SIGNAL>SPI_SMC_CS_L</SIGNAL> 3.31v (measured at pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R6117</RESISTOR>)

I checked resistance to ground on MOSI and CLK:
MOSI 623 Ω  (measured at pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R6115</RESISTOR>)
CLK 560  Ω (measured at pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R6116</RESISTOR>)

I then went through and measured the resistance across all 22 SPI resistors.
All matched their values.

I assume the MOSI and CLK should not be zero volts?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not display on int or ext screen. Orange light and fan spins,
threads.message:
"I assume the MOSI and CLK should not be zero volts?"
Wrong assumption; is exactly as should be.
When have such doubts, just check working board on similar points.

Did you really remove <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>/01 and check their pads underneath?

"I then went through and measured the resistance across all 22 SPI resistors."
What about connection traces between them?

J6100 may need to be removed.
Just in case, try known good BIOS; corrupted BIOS was sometimes reported in case of liquid damage.
